Early Access Review
								I'm scared of heights, so this game certainly pushed all of those buttons...now I realize I wasn't really scared of heights, I was scared of not having jetpacks attached to my elbows. 10/10 - Would get over my fear of heights again by attaching jetpacks to my elbows. It's worth noting, this game has crashed both times I've tried to play it, and I only get a good 10-15 mins in before it happens. Only game that's done that so far. I monitor my hardware's stats, and not seeing anything that'd explain it on that end. Either way, crashing or not, this game is fun and worth trying. Still recommend.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 3
Early Access Review
								A great deal of unrealized potential.There are guns that hint that there might be some sort of combat. There are hidden sections in a few of the areas that hint that there might be some scheme to "break free" of the standard areas. There is dialogue that hints that this is not the most legitimate facility and that you should be attempting to break free. There are courses that suggest you should be able to fly outside of the course itself.None of this is ever realized in any parts of the game I ever came across. There is NOTHING to shoot, not even a single thing in any area that even responds to being shot, not even leaving burn textures behind that would at least allow you to pretend you were shooting targets. There is one area that doesn't seem to have any bounding box,(space) but all that does is make it almost impossible to find your way back if you go too far.However this may all change in a future update. For what it is, the controls and gun/flight mechanics are... interesting. They could stand to change the angle the the thruster gun objects are in relation to the Vive wands, which could make them more comfortable to use, but for the most part, the flight itself is an enjoyable experience. I use a constant floor bounding area in my Vive settings though, which may have helped reduce nausea, as the flight is apparently too much for some people to handle, at least from what some of the discussions and other reviews have mentioned.I recommend this game, really only because it is free. If it cost even a single dollar, I would expect at least some sort of content (missions to carry out, targets to shoot, secrets to find? something?) before it would be worth that investment, but for free, the only requirements I have behind my recommendation is that the VR is stable and basic controls work as expected. That much it succeeds in with flying colors.Just as a side note, the highest speed I was able to achieve was around 1300km/s. I didn't notice any particularly effect approaching a blueshift.

Posted: December 29, 2016
Early Access Review
Incomplete, partially broken experience that you just have to try.Blueshift, formerly known as Brian's High Velocity Research Center, is a must-try VR experience.  You get to take off like a plane or glide across the ground like a skateboarder with rockets. That said, the best aspect of this isn't gameplay but the scale of the objects, which gives you a sense of both vertigo and excitement.The game is far from polished and nowhere near a completely developed environment.  There are many holes or missing areas in the environment which ruin immersion and cause confusion.  There are also some quality of life features missing entirely, like the back button to choose another level or a compass to locate the ship that takes you back.  When you go back to the main level, it just teleports you back into the starting position rather than giving you a way to move back into the level selection room from the place you were.  The levels differ greatly, which is good, but the gameplay mechanics change between levels a little more than I'd like.  The wings only show up on land levels, for example.This game needs some love from its developer, but it shows a lot of potential.  It's worth trying, because it's free after all.

Posted: December 22, 2016
Early Access Review
								Brian's High Velocity Research Center (besides being a long name to type) is an incredibly fun flying game. Attached to both your hands you have guns that can shoot and be used as jetpacks that also can spout wings (it sounds weird but makes total sense while playing). The game feauters no enemies (at least that I saw) and allows you to fly (and ski like in the Tribes games) across giant maps and landscapes. The game is incredibly fun and gave me no motion sickness (despite the incredible speeds you go at). Despite being free the game does not sacrifice graphics or gameplay for the price and I completely reccomend it for anyone looking for a fun, relaxing unique experience.

Posted: December 30, 2016
Early Access Review
								Amazing feeling of movement.  I was blown away by how good it feels skimming across these huge maps and busting out the wings for some flight.   There are great levels already, and lots of them.  The lunar level gives you less gravity and the space level lets you fly around with no gravity.  Standing on the space station and looking out over the planet below was so awesome.  and that was just one of the times in this game that gave me one of those "VR moments".No VR sickness at all and some bad loco or bad framerates will give me VR sickness.  Watching the videos of people playing it early on, I thought I'd be trying it for a few minutes and then dropping out because of motion sickness, but I didn't have any effects and played over half an hour so far..Can't wait to see where the dev takes this.

Posted: January 7
Early Access Review
								I see talk of motionsickness issues. I agree there are portions which are like that, but the open areas are much better than the home tutorial map. It is very closed off, therefore your perception of the fast motion is greater. It took me w hile to learn the gradual thruster control (Don't click touch pad, but just touch it, and the thrust increases from bottom of the touchpad to the top. Click the touchpad for full thrust no matter what part of the touchpad you are clicking.) Another way to help motion sickness on this one is to stay seated in a swivel chair. That especially helps when navigating closed areas, and the slide-coasters.Better name! Would like to see more interactivity with objects. Maybe I missed it on one ov the levels, but I did not see any use for the guns. Even target practice while soaring and attempting to control your flight path would be a fun challenge! Or there could be targets along the sides of the different slide-coasters! Looking forward to your next developments! I'd be willing to pay for this title with additions like those. Keep up the good work!

Posted: February 9
Early Access Review
For those who don't realise, this game is being developed by the dev of VertigoHot damn,  this game.I am not usually one to write reviewsfor games - I actually couldn't tell you the last time I did it, or the game I did it for without going and checking now. I don't get any kind of motion sickness at all (Though, to be fair, I'm yet to have a game give me any kind of nausea).Honestly, even if you only have a spare 10 minutes to have a little play around, I can assure you this free little gem is 100% worth your time. Posted: January 26
Early Access Review
								Stioll buggy, but that is to be expected for an early access game that is clearly being developed by a garage team, or just a dude in a garage.  That said, it is very fun, the concept is solid and the potential shines through.  Mine bugged out on the returns, so I had to keep shutting it down and reloadiong to tyry a different world, but still, the potential for deathmatches in these spaces was clear, and would be a blast.  Combo downhill/slalom with deathmatch thrown in, kind of like rollerderby with guns, would be a blast, among other things, and I look forward to seeing how it progresses.  Download it, have ten minutes of fun, then kep an eye on it over teh coming months.  Dufusses who post negative reviews about an Early Access game not being fully realized and buggy should be banned from Steam, not to mention the prat who gave a Not Recommended because he didn't have a VR headset yet.  ID10T's aside, this is a free game, and as such is worth every penny.  In the future, I have high hopes.
